IMAGE-HIGH-RES MOLCAA 8440 S1381-1169(12)00180-X 10.1016/j.molcata.2012.05.023 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Molecular structure of the supramolecular species constituted by meso-tetrapyridylporphyrin zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II) coordinated to four [Ru(bipy)2Cl]+ (bipy=2,2′-bipyridine)/four [Ru(phen)2Cl]+ (phen=1,10-phenanthroline)/four [Ru(bidypy)2Cl]+ (bidypy=2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate). Fig. 2 Setup of the photoreduction system pressure bottle (CO2), (2) reducing valve, (3) pump, (4) rotameter, (5) CO2 storage tank (100L), (6) closing valve, (7) inlet of water, (8) magnetic stirrer, (9) magnetic bar, (10) photoreactor, (11) source (Xe lamp), (12) outlet of water, (13) cool fanner, and (14) pressure gage. (A) Gas chromatograph gas sample and (B) gas chromatograph liquid sample. Fig. 3 TEM images of TiO2 nanotube (dried at 80°C). Fig. 4 TEM images of TiO2 nanotube (calcined at 400°C. The insert is the ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy-TNT). Fig. 5 HRTEM of the TiO2 nanotubes (calcined at 400°C. The insert is the electron diffraction pattern). Fig. 6 XRD spectra of (1) titania nanotube (dried at 80°C for 4h in air), (2) titania nanotube (calcined at 400°C in air for 2h), and (3) P25. Fig. 7 FT-IR spectra of P25, titania nanotube, ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy-TNT, and CuPyP-RuPhen-TNT. Fig. 8 Time dependence of methane yield by using different catalysts. Reduction of CO2 aqueous solution by using photosensitized-TiO2 nanotube catalysts modified by supramolecular metalloporphyrins-ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes Chen Wang a b c Xiao-Xun Ma a b c ⁎ Jun Li d Long Xu a b c Feng-xing Zhang d a School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People's Republic of China b Chemical Engineering Research Center of the Ministry of Education for Advanced Use Technology of Shanbei Energy, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People's Republic of China c Shaanxi Research Center of Engineering Technology for Clean Coal Conversion, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People's Republic of China d Key Laboratory of Synthetic and Natural Functional Molecule Chemistry of the Ministry of Education, School of Chemistry & Materials Science, Northwest University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People's Republic of China ⁎ Corresponding author at: School of Chemical Engineering, Northwest University, Xi’an, Shaanxi 710069, People's Republic of China. Graphical abstract The photosensitized semiconductor catalysts – TiO2 nanotubes – were modified by functionalized supramolecular sensitizers: zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II) porphyrin-ruthenium(II) polypyridly complexes and photocatalytic activity of the modified TiO2 nanotubes were investigated through the reduction of CO2 aqueous solution as a probe reaction under UV–vis light. The diverse photoreduction properties of the catalysts were resulted from the different polypyridly derivatives: 2,2′-bipyridyl, 1,10-phenanthroline, and 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate. The different central coordinated metal ions in porphyrin ring influence the photocatalytic efficiency of the sensitized-TiO2 system at the same time. A possible mechanism of the photocatalytic reduction was also proposed in this paper. Highlights ► Novel supramolecular photosensitizers TiO2 nanotube catalysts were synthesized. ► The TiO2 nanotube photocatalytic in CO2 reduction have not been report at present. ► All the photosensitizers enhanced the catalytic efficiency of bare TiO2 nanotube. ► The modified TiO2 catalysts displayed good methanol selectivity. ► A possible mechanism of the photocatalytic reduction was proposed in this paper. The photosensitized semiconductor catalysts – TiO2 nanotubes – were modified by functionalized supramolecular sensitizers: zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II) porphyrin-ruthenium(II) polypyridly complexes and photocatalytic activity of the modified TiO2 nanotubes were investigated through the reduction of CO2 aqueous solution as a probe reaction under UV–vis light. The diverse photoreduction properties of the catalysts resulted from the different polypyridly derivatives: 2,2′-bipyridyl, 1,10-phenanthroline, and 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate. The different central coordinated metal ions in the porphyrin ring influenced the photocatalytic efficiency of the sensitized-TiO2 system at the same time. A possible mechanism for the photocatalytic reduction was also proposed in this paper. Keywords TiO2 nanotubes Photosensitizers CO2 Reduction Methanol 1 Introduction The ever-increasing CO2 concentration in the atmosphere has become a major concern, so there is an urgent need to discover carbon-neutral sources of energy. Compared with energy saving and emission reduction, CO2 recovery and utilization is a more positive method. So transformation of the CO2 to hydrocarbons by some photocatalysts, especially modified TiO2, under light/solar irradiation, has been a topic of growing interest in recent years [1–4]. Various chemicals such as methane, methanol, ethanol, formaldehyde, and formic acid can be formed in the process of CO2 reduction [5,6]. Methanol is one of the most expectant reduction products because it is not only a very important industrial chemical but also an ideal fuel for new energy-saving and environment-friendly vehicles. Thus, improving methanol selectivity and yield from CO2 reduction by proper catalyst is a meaningful topic [7,8]. As one of the most promising n-type semiconductor materials, TiO2 has attracted considerable attention in the last several decades due to its excellent performance in the photocatalyst and photoelectric conversion areas [9–12], and this trend has become more popular and developed more rapidly after TiO2 nanotube was synthesized in 1998 by Kasuga et al. [13]. Nevertheless, the change in the morphology of nanotube cannot extend the absorption in the range of visible light since it is still a wide band gap material and it cannot absorb the light with a wave length of over 387nm, so this drawback limits its maximum utilization of the free, clean, and inexhaustible solar energy because more than 45% of solar radiation lies in the visible light range. Therefore, it is necessary to extend its property for absorbing visible light. Photosensitization is an efficient method, which has shown greater capability in TiO2 visible light response than other methods such as metals and non-metals ion doping, ion implantation [14]. Up until now, a variety of photo-sensitizers with different structures were synthesized so as to obtain modified TiO2 catalysts [15–17], whose light absorption range was within the visible light region. Metalloporphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridyl complexes were screened out from numerous sensitizers due to their prominent performance in this regard [18–20]. This kind of supramolecular sensitizer assembled with one porphyrin molecule in the center with four peripheral ruthenium polypyridyl molecules has intense absorption of visible light and high quantum yield. Above all, electron and energy transfer goes smoothly between porphyrin and polypyridyl molecules due to their similar energy levels, and their stable structure enables them to be used under harsh reaction conditions when impregnated onto the TiO2 surface. In fact, metalloporphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridyl complexes modified TiO2 systems were widely applied in the photo electrochemistry research field, such as DSSC, photosensitized electrodes [21,22]. But this system with photocatalytic reduction of CO2 aqueous solution to methanol has not been reported yet. Therefore, we synthesized a series of metalloporphyrin-ruthenium(II) polypyridyl supramolecules with several different structures as the sensitizers to investigate their photosensitized behavior in modifying TiO2. The photocatalytic activities of the modified TiO2 were investigated by reducing the CO2 aqueous solution to methanol as a probe reaction under UV–vis light. In addition to methanol, some other gas phase products generated during the photoreaction process were also studied. Different structures of the metalloporphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridyl complexes will influence the efficiency of modified TiO2 photocatalytic properties via charge-separated excited states or intra/intermolecular energy transfers between TiO2. So it is significant to design and screen metalloporphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridyl complexes with appropriate structures to improve the efficiency of the photosensitized-TiO2 system. The photosensitizers include Zn(II), Cu(II), and Co(II) porphyrin assembled with ruthenium(II) polypyridly complexes, and the polypyridly ligands include 2,2′-bipyridyl, 1,10-phenanthroline and 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate (Fig. 1 ). It is worth noting that the crystal form and morphology of TiO2 is more important than photosensitizers to a certain extent in the photocatalytic behavior [23,24]. Generally, TiO2 nanotube has a more specific surface area and better photochemical and catalytic properties than commercial P25. We synthesized anatase TiO2 nanotube with a diameter of 7nm and a length of 10–100nm via the hydrothermal method. It is expected to display excellent properties when modified by sensitizers during the process of photoreducing CO2 to methanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and measurements RuCl3·H2O, 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate were obtained from Aldrich, P25 was obtained from Degussa Corporation, Germany, and other reagents were obtained from Tianjin Chemical Reagents Company. They were used without further purification except pyrrole, which was distilled before use. The specific surface area was determined by the BET method. Nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherms were measured on a Micromeritics ASAP-2010. The crystals of prepared precursors and products were analyzed by powder X-ray diffractometer (Shimadzu 6000) using Cu Kα radiation (λ: 0.15416nm). High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was carried out by using a JEOL JEM-3010 instrument. FT-IR spectra were recorded on a BEQ UZNDX-550 spectrometer on samples embedded in KBr pellets. The gas and liquid phase samples were analyzed by using gas chromatograph – Agilent Technologies 6890N with FID and TCD detectors and the Molsieve and HP Poraplot Q columns, the details of the analytical methods were the same as reference [25]. 2.2 General procedure for the preparation of titanate nanotubes and photosensitizers Titanate nanotubes were prepared under hydrothermal conditions according to Ref. [26]. 2.0g P25 was added to 60mL of 10M NaOH solution under vigorous stirring for 24h at rt. The solution was transferred into a PTFE lined stainless steel autoclave and kept for 72h at 130°C. Then the product was separated by high-speed centrifuge and washed with dilute hydrochloric acid for 2h to remove the Na+ ions. Then the product was washed with de-ionized water several times until the pH value reached 7. After centrifuge, the white powder samples were dried in a furnace for 4h at 80°C. Finally, the product was calcined for 2h at 400°C and the anatase phases titanate nanotubes were obtained. All the photosensitizers were synthesized according to the Refs. [27–29]. The photosensitizers include: μ-meso-[(5,10,15,20-tetra-4-pyridylporphyrinato) zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II)] tetrakis [chloro-2,2′-bipyridyl-ruthenium(II)] tetrahexafluorophosphate (labeled as ZnPyP-RuBiPy, CuPyP-RuBiPy, CoPyP-RuBiPy). μ-meso-[(5,10,15,20-tetra-4-pyridylporphyrinato) zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II)] tetrakis [chloro-(1,10-phenanthroline)-ruthenium(II)] tetrahexafluorophosphate (labeled as ZnPyP-RuPhen, CuPyP-RuPhen, CoPyP-RuPhen). μ-meso-[(5,10,15,20-tetra-4-pyridylporphyrinato) zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt (II)] tetrakis [chloro-(2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate)-ruthenium(II)] tetrahexafluorophosphate (labeled as ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy, CuPyP-RuBiDiPy, CoPyP-RuBiDiPy). 2.3 Preparation of the photocatalyts The loaded samples used as photocatalysts for the reduction experiments were prepared by impregnating 1g of TiO2 nanotube with 1.0×10−4 mmol/L of the sensitizer Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuBiPy, Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuPhen or Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuBiDiPy in the following way respectively. The sensitizer was dissolved in 20mL of acetonitrile and 1g of TiO2 nanotube was added to this solution. The resulting suspension was stirred and refluxed for 8h in the dark under nitrogen atmosphere. The suspension was filtered and the remaining solid was washed with water until the filtrate turned colorless. Then the solid power was dried at rt. under high vacuum. 2.4 Photoreactivity experiments The photo-reduction setup is shown in Fig. 2 The setup consisted of a 300mL beaker irradiated by the UV–vis light provide by a 500W, 24V xenon lamp-house system (CHF-XM 35–500W, Beijing Trusttech Co., Ltd., P.R. China). The reaction solution was about 2cm away from the lamp in distance, where the light intensity was 0.85W/cm2 (New Port Dual-Channel Power Meter, model 2832-C, Irvine, CA). The temperature inside the reactor was maintained at ca. 323K by means of a continuous circulation of water in a jacket surrounding the reactor. The reacting suspension containing 250mL 0.05mol/L NaOH solution, 0.05mol/L Na2SO3 as the electron donors and 50.0mg of catalyst was magnetically stirred and had CO2 bubbled into the suspension for 30min before switching on the lamp. A 100L storage tank was filled with CO2 at the beginning and pressure was kept in the range of 1.1–1.2bar during the photoreduction process. That is to say the total reaction system is closed and the CO2 has been recycled. The photoreduction runs for 300min, and samples were withdrawn from the suspension every 60min during the irradiation. The photocatalysts were separated from the solution by filtration, and the quantitative determination of liquid and gaseous composition was determined by GC. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The TiO2 nanotubes and photosensitized-TNT catalysts From the TEM images, it can be measured that the length of the nanotube was more than 300nm (Fig. 3 ) before being calcined at 400°C and was about 10–100nm (Fig. 4 ) after that. The outer diameter of the nanotubes was about 7nm and the inner diameter about 3nm. The walls of the nanotubes contain 3–5 layers, and all the nanotubes have open ends. The HRTEM image (Fig. 5 ) indicates that the interplaner distance was 0.34nm between the two adjacent parallel fringes [30], which corresponded to the interplaner distance of anatase {101} and the SAED image (the inset in Fig. 5) also shows that the TiO2 nanotube has a multicrystal structure anatase phase in which the diffraction rings are the (101), (004), (200), and (105) crystal faces respectively [31]. Compared with P25 containing rutile (30%) and anatase (70%) phase, the TiO2 nanotube was amorphous when dried in a furnace at 80°C and was transformed into pure anatase after being calcined at 400°C according to XRD image (Fig. 6 ). 3D lattice structure was not formed between layers during the process when monolayer titanate sheet was curled to form the tubular structure in the alkaline solution [32], so when the TiO2 nanotube was amorphous, there was no clear diffraction peak in the XRD image. The chemical bond was formed between the layers of the nanotube walls after being calcined at 400°C, so the nanotube structure was transformed into the anatase phase. The characteristic diffraction peak of the anatase crystal faces, including (101), (004), (200), (105), (211), and (204) can be seen in the XRD image. The dispersion state and morphology of the TiO2 nanotube (TNT) did not change after the sensitizer was impregnated onto its surface (the inset in Fig. 4). In addition, because the sensitizer molecules were not doped into the TiO2 crystal lattice but were only impregnated onto its surface, the photosensitizers modification hardly had any effect on the crystal structure of TiO2 nanotube. The FT-IR spectra of P25, titania nanotube (dried at 400°C for 4h in air), ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy-TNT and CuPyP-RuPhen-TNT are displayed in Fig. 7 The absorption peak at 3420cm−1 is associated with the stretching vibrations of surface hydroxyl groups TiO2. Further observation shows that the peak of the bare titania nanotube at 3420cm−1 was broader and stronger than that of P25 because larger surface areas adsorbed more hydroxyl groups, but the peak was weakened later when the sensitizers were loaded on the surface of TNT and took the place of the hydroxyl groups. Similarly, this trend was also reflected in the bending vibration of HOH groups and TiOH bonds at 1640cm−1 for all samples. The strong and broad peaks around 600cm−1 were attributed to the characteristic peaks of anatase TiO2 and TNT. The faint stretching vibrations of CC, CH bonds at 1630cm−1 and 3010cm−1 respectively can be observed in modified TNT composites, indicating that there are sensitizers on the surface of the TNT. 3.2 Photoreactivity experiments The photocatalytic activities for the reduction of the CO2 aqueous solution under UV–vis light irradiation using prepared photocatalysts were investigated. As expected, it showed that the bare TiO2 nanotubes and photosensitized TiO2 nanotube photocatalysts displayed higher photocatalytic efficiency for reduction of CO2 aqueous suspension in comparison with the result obtained by using bare P25 via GC detection. Fig. 8 shows the evolution of methanol concentration in the liquid product. It is worth noting that only methanol was detected in the liquid phase under the experiment condition but other liquid products such as formaldehyde and formic acid were not detected [33]. The methanol concentration continued to increase and peaked after 4–4.5h of irradiation, and then started decreasing slowly. The BET value of the TiO2 nanotube is 2.7 times of P25, but the methanol yield is 4 times of P25 when the nanotube is used as the catalyst, so it can be concluded that the efficiency is not only determined by the surface area, but more importantly, by the superior property of nanotube over nanoparticle (P25). The gas phase products were determined during the photoreaction process as well. The main products were hydrogen and methane, but carbon monoxide, ethane, and ethylene, were not detected under our experiment condition although they could also be generated [34]. When ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy-TNT was used as the photocatalyst in this experiment, hydrogen has been detected after 30min of irradiation and its concentration increased steadily, but methane has not been detected until 2h later. After 5h, the observed hydrogen concentration was 18.5 times higher than that of methane. Table 1 reports the relevant photocatalytic results for different catalysts under UV–vis light irradiation. The data displayed obvious differences in the photocatalytic activity. For example, the experiment with ZnPyP-RuBiDiPy-TNT as the photocatalyst, indicated that the methanol concentration increased to 746μmolL−1 g−1 cat after 4.5h of irradiation under UV–vis light, and the hydrogen and methane yield were 130μmolL−1 g−1 cat, 7.2μmolL−1 g−1 cat after 5h, respectively. It can be clearly seen that the photocatalytic activity, which is determined according to the methanol yield, decreased in the following order when using the ZnPyP-Ru(II)polypyridly TNT photocatalysts: ZnPyP-RuBiDipy-TNT>ZnPyP-RuPhen-TNT>ZnPyP-RuBiPy-TNT. Similarly, Cu(II) or Co(II) porphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridly TNT shows the same photocatalytic reduction rule. These results could be explained by different molecular structures. The supramolecules have the same metalloporphyrin center but different peripheral Ru(II) polypyridly ligands, such as 2,2′-bipyridyl, 1,10-phenanthroline and 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate respectively. Phenanthroline has a better conjugated structure and π-electrons flowing capability than bipyridyl, which means phenanthroline complex is easier to be excited than bipyridyl complex, so it has higher intramolecular energy and electron transfer efficiency (referring to transfer between center metalloporphyrin and peripheral Ru(II) polypyridly) than bipyridyl complex, leading to the result that photocatalytic activity of Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuPhen-TNT is higher than Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuBiPy-TNT. Although bipyridyl has the same conjugated structure with its dicarboxylate derivative, the existence of carboxyl changes the binding mode of the sensitizer molecule with TiO2. Generally, the sensitizer molecule can combine with TiO2 via the physisorption mode, but they can easily combine with each other by forming a more compact and stable covalent bond via the dehydratation or dehydrogenation processes if the sensitizer molecule contains hydroxyl group or carboxyl group [35,36]. Undoubtedly, chemical bonding is a more efficient than physisorption in the intermolecular (which means between sensitizer and TiO2) energy and electron transfer process, which is conducive to injecting the excited electrons generated from the excited Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuBiDipy to the CB of the TiO2, so that it has more effective photosensitive activity than Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuBiPy and Zn/Cu/CoPyP-RuPhen. In addition, the different coordinated metal ions in the porphyrin ring influenced the photoreduction efficiency of the sensitized-TNT catalysts even though their effects are slightly different, e.g., the photocatalytic activity decreased in the following order when using the Zn(II)/Cu(II)/Co(II) PyP-Ru(II)BiDipy-TNT as photocatalysts: ZnPyP-RuBiDipy-TNT>CuPyP-RuBiDipy-TNT>CoPyP-RuBiDipy-TNT. Moreover, Fe(III)/Mn(III) porphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridly have not displayed any sensitizing effects when they were impregnated onto the TNT compared with bare TNT according to our contrast experiments. Metal ion decides whether the sensitizer has the suitable redox-active center, which is a very important element to a redox reaction [37]. 3.3 Process features and mechanistic aspects Though the detailed mechanism of the photocatalytic reduction of the CO2 aqueous solution by using photosensitized-TiO2 has not been fully understood, some basic processes and major steps have been proposed [33,38–40]. Classically, a series of free radical reactions will be initiated by photon-generated excited electrons and valence band holes which are formed by excited TiO2 under UV light irradiation (Eq. (1)). Nevertheless, the photosensitizer molecule, such as metalloporphyrin-Ru(II) polypyridly, is more easily excited via one photon transition (hν) to its excited state than TiO2 under the UV or visible light due to its absorption characteristics. Specifically, metalloporphyrin, which is located at the center of the supramolecular, transfers the excited electrons or energy to peripheral Ru(II) polypyridly (Eqs. (2), (3), (5), and (6)). Admittedly, the inverse process cannot be excluded. Then, the excited electrons can be transferred into the conduction-band of the TiO2 and realize the energy transfer process (Eqs. (4) and (7)). However, peripheral Ru(II) polypyridly cannot only play a role of a bridge but can also yield electrons via light irradiation and transfer electrons to TiO2 directly as an independent sensitization unit. (1) TiO 2 ⟶ h v e − ( TiO 2 ) + h + ( TiO 2 ) (2) [ MPp-RuPy ] ⟶ h v [ MPp * -RuPy ] (3) [MPp*-RuPy]→[MPp-RuPy*] (4) [MPp-RuPy*]→[MPp-RuPy+]+e− (5) [MPp*-RuPy]→[MPp+(e−)-RuPy] (6) [MPp+(e−)-RuPy]→[MPp-RuPy+(e−)] (7) [MPp-RuPy+(e−)]→[MPp-RuPy+]+(e−) Then, the hole reacts with H2O and produces O2 and H+ (Eq. (8)) or reacts with OH and produces a hydroxyl radical (Eq. (9)). The excited electron reacts with H+ and forms H radical (Eq. (10)). Hydroxyl radical and H radical will lead to consecutive reactions and produce methanol, H2 or methane (Eqs. (11)–(20)). (8) 2 h + + H 2 O → 1 2 O 2 + 2 H + (9) h+ +OH− → OH (10) H+ +e− → H (11) CO2 +e− → CO2 − (12) CO2 − + H→CO+OH− (13) CO+e− → CO− (14) CO− + H→C+OH− (15) C+ H→ CH (16) CH+ H→CH2 (17) CH2 + H→ CH3 (18) CH3 + H→CH4 (19) CH3 + OH→CH3OH (20) H+ H→H2 In fact, the combination of CO2 and an excited electron to form CO2 − is an extremely difficult process in thermodynamics. For instance, the standard electrochemical potential of the CO2 to CO2 − is −1.90V (vs. NHE in aqueous solution at pH 7) but CO2 to CH3OH or CH4 is only −0.38V and −0.24V, respectively [41]. That is to say, CO2 reduction via proton assisted multi-electron-transfer pathways is much more favorable than direct one-electron reduction in thermodynamics [42]. However, energy intensive and unfavorable processes in terms of thermodynamics do not mean extremely difficulty in kinetics. After all, the CO2 reduction reaction does take place in practice. However, it is a rapid process in which CO gains one electron and is reduced to CO− (Eq. (13)), followed by a series of chain reactions (Eqs. (14)–(19)), so we have not detected CO in gas phase products. As we know, many factors will influence the products of CO2 reduction, such as TiO2 crystal form and structure [23,24,43,44], molecular structure of the sensitizer [6,45,46] and reduction condition [47]. The formaldehyde and formic acid in liquid phase were not detected under our test condition. This could be because the structure of nanotube and sensitizer limits the formation of formaldehyde and formic acid (Eqs. (21) and (22)) through the combination of CO2 − radical with H+ in strong alkali solution. Furthermore, free radicals and catalyst surface are connected by a transition state structure during the free radicals formation, which makes it relatively more stable than individual free radicals. Therefore, the CHx radicals are immobilized on catalyst surface; different from H or OH radicals, they cannot combine with each other to form other hydrocarbons such as ethane (21) C O 2 − + 4 H + + 3 e − ⟶ − H 2 O HCHO (22) CO2 − +2H+ +e− →HCOOH In addition, the O2 formed by the hole and H2O could lead to the photooxidation of the reverse reaction. The reduction process and the reduction yields will be limited by the oxidation process, so adding excess sacrificial agents or electron donors in the photoreduction system is necessary, such as SO3 2−, and I−. Meanwhile, the excited sensitizer which has lost electrons will regenerate by sacrificial agents or electron donors and return to the ground state. 4 Conclusion In our research, supramolecules containing zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II) porphyrins and ruthenium(II) polypyridyl/complexes and TiO2 nanotubes were synthesized along with the corresponding modified TiO2 nanotube-based photocatalysts. It can be concluded that sensitizers with different structures, such as coordinated metals in porphyrin and peripheral polypyridly ligands, have different photosensitized efficiency when they are impregnated onto the TiO2 surface. ZnPyP-RuBiDipy-TNT shows the best efficiency in photoreduction CO2 aqueous solution to methanol. All the photosensitized catalysts exhibited superior selectivity in liquid products during this process. Undoubtedly, photoreduction CO2 by H2O is a very difficult process because CO2 is an extremely inert and thermodynamically stable molecule. But high efficiency phototsensitized-TNT catalyst brings us hope and opportunities. Transformation of the CO2 to methanol by photocatalyst under light irradiation, especially under solar irradiation, is a significant topic in the energy-chemical industry and the environmental conservation area although the methanol yield was too low to be used in the practical industry at present. A more efficient potocatalyst needs to be designed and improved in the future. coredata.dc:description: The photosensitized semiconductor catalysts – TiO2 nanotubes – were modified by functionalized supramolecular sensitizers: zinc(II)/copper(II)/cobalt(II) porphyrin-ruthenium(II) polypyridly complexes and photocatalytic activity of the modified TiO2 nanotubes were investigated through the reduction of CO2 aqueous solution as a probe reaction under UV–vis light. The diverse photoreduction properties of the catalysts resulted from the different polypyridly derivatives: 2,2′-bipyridyl, 1,10-phenanthroline, and 2,2′-bipyridyl-4,4′-dicarboxylate. The different central coordinated metal ions in the porphyrin ring influenced the photocatalytic efficiency of the sensitized-TiO2 system at the same time. A possible mechanism for the photocatalytic reduction was also proposed in this paper.
coredata.dc:title: Reduction of CO2 aqueous solution by using photosensitized-TiO2 nanotube catalysts modified by supramolecular metalloporphyrins-ruthenium(II) polypyridyl complexes
